reviewText:
Who wants a review from a die hard Super Hexagon fan? Well look right here.

I have 100+ seconds in every level on Super Hexagon so beating the first two levels in Unpossible was pretty easy already. There's only three real levels and trying to beat them when you're super experienced at Super Hexagon and Open Hexagon makes completing the game a breeze. I was able to complete this game relatively quickly.

Now the LAST level was pretty difficult in my own opinion and pretty fun, but I didn't like the rings that made you rotate around that cylinder liked wire looking thing that you're always rotating around. It was basically a test of How long can I tap the left/right arrow key without messing up" rather than "How well can I react based on reflex." I also really dislike how I can't use a mouse instead of a keyboard but that's just my preference.

Compared to other rage quit games (Super Hexagon
recommended: and Geometry Dash for examples)... This game

reviewText:
A pretty fun and nice-looking reflex game. It has 3 modes of difficulty: Simplicity, Futile, and Ultra, and every time you play,  the stage is more or less random with obstacles placed in a different pattern. You do get some types of obstacles more common in one difficulty than another, but their placement and pattern often varies. Your goal is to last as long as you can.

For each difficulty level you also get a special daily stage. This stage only changes after every 24 hours, so if you're not a fan of the randomness aspect, you can always play the daily stage and try to memorize your way through it.

There isn't much else that this game offers, so my only critique so far is that it needs more content, perhaps in a form of more game modes (not necessarily difficulty, but just different goals), but what it does have is pretty fun if you fancy to test your reflexes, precision, and decisiveness, and it costs hardly anything.

reviewText:
The idea of the game is very simplistic. Player should avoid obstacles while moving along its path. It's kinda like Wipeout Zone mode, but only without Zones.
The idea is very fun. However, there comes couple some catches you wouldn't want this game.
1. There is no progression. Your path is just the same 10 seconds, 60 seconds or 300 seconds into the game, so eventually it becomes boring.
2. There are literally no settings. No sound volume, no screen resolution selection (thanks god it picks up your current desktop resolution), no windowed mode. I do understand why it's fine for a mobile game, but it's totally not fine for a PC game.
3. The game plays very good with a controller. But... there are no support for a controller in a main menu. So the game is over (and it will happen quite often) you have to lean for your mouse.
4. Achievements page opens steam browser, which causes your mouse cursor to disappear. And since you need it to start a new game, things become a little problematic.

This might not be much, but it really breaks experience. Got the game for like 1$, still is not worth it. I'll prbably leave the game on a follow list, and will buy it again if I get like 75% discount, or those issues will be patched.

reviewText:
The game has a nice atmosphere by having nice graphics and soundtracks.

No idea once more again, like in all the other games, what the developer was thinking by doing this mistake.

There are 3 levels of difficulty:
Simplicity
Futile
Ultra
And each one has a random and a memory based distance. The memory based distance changes each day.

reviewText: just bought this game alot of fun but my mouse seems to be invisible at times
Awesome Game

A nice little gae you can play in between without having to invest too much time, attention or patience.\nThe looks are quite fine, and so is the music.\nNot sure whether I would have paid the - kinda high - full price for it though.

As a short review it's a great game that introduces a very well designed 3D feel to the reaction game genre. For a pretty low price of $3 (as of 16/12/2015) it definitely should provide a few hours of gameplay.

As a more critical review here are some points to consider:
1. Sensitivity is really hard to get right. Depending on what obstacles you face it's either too sensitive for small precise gaps or too slow for long winding turns. For a reaction based game it's somewhat annoying to not have a perfect sensitivity that matches the games design of obstacles.
2. Other than the few hours of gameplay I mentioned at the start I don't see this game being playable after that. Yes there are achievements but they are somewhat boring (for instance achieving 60 seconds on a certain level on 30 DIFFERENT DAYS? I get they're trying to make you play for longer but it's just boring and meaningless and there's no real sense of achievement).
3. Music is questionable at times. For a cheap game it's not awful but it could definitely have been designed to be more dramatic rather than just mere electronic background noise.
4. Visuals could have been so much better. I'm probably just being cynical at this point but considering this game was available previously for IOS and android and was originally released as $10 on steam the developers surely had some budget to ramp up the lighting in the game and sharpen the visuals (the black with blue neons had so much potential to reminiscence TRON).

Other than that I adore the sensation of being inside the game this gives you compared to my typical reaction games like the impossible game or super hexagon.

Unpossible does its title justice. If you are not experienced with a game that puts you on a single track and throws random obstacles at you, prepare for a challenge.

While the first difficulty setting (Simplicity) is rather easy, the upper two (Futile, Ultra) will surely challenge you.

Additionally with the challenge of just reaching a minute on these difficulties this game comes with a exceptionally good music and artstyle - so well made actually that it might distract you a little from the track at first.

I do recommend this game to anyone who is looking for a little challenge.

Its really fun. It can be improved a lot especially with different texture themes and more music. In the future I expect this will be a really fun game that is very casual when you have a bit of free time to open up and play. Currently hoping on getting mouse support (so its more smooth than wasd).

I really loved this game on mobile (android) so much that I was waiting for the game to be greenlit and added on steam. At last, it finally went on steam!

As for the review go, it may be biased, but who cares.

The optimization is pretty neat, however, since I have a pretty beefy computer and it's still not at 60 fps but I can play games like crysis on highest settings and get 60+ fps

But putting fps aside, I just enjoy this game because the music + reflex interactions

Also, if you alt-tab out of the game and go back, the controller settings will get messed up / wont be able to see mouse. Have to close the game and relaunch to fix this problem

I wish the game wouldnt pause every time i tab out, and wish there was an continue audio in background" option because I like the music"

reviewText:
Upossible is a First-Person, racing, fast paced indie game that is about as good as it is difficult. So very fun! But, also, very difficult!

In Unpossible, you bassically try to get at least a score of 60 seconds, to go on to the other levels. The levels get more difficult as you progress. There isn't a story in the game, since it's just a game where you beat your high score on each level. For example, the easiest level, (Daily Simplicity), is easy to get a high score. But, in higher and more advanced levels, such as Futile, its's more challenging, and requires you to think fast and on the spot about where you need to go, making getting a high score moe difficult as you progress. The only controls are A and D, so there isn't much complexity there, either.

Overall, this game is really fun. I recommend it to everyone. Plus, it is a very cheap game, so, it's not hard to aquire a copy.
Unpossiable is one of the best games that Ive played in a long time. It runs smoothly and it provides a decent challege to who ever plays it. It's a lot of fun.
Fun and fast paced, very easy to loose your self trying to get a higher score. Challenging with out being frustrating, I have never once felt the need to rage quite.
